引文问题就是这样。当我们将我们的公司卖给Chegg时，我们已经接触到了五分之四需要参考书目的学生，或者是美国教育技术公司(EdTech Companies)的超过3000万名学生，这些公司帮助学生解决数学、化学、家庭作业帮助、辅导和其他课程需求，可以迅速建立起大量受众。

这些挑战肯定是可以克服的。但作为一家初创公司，我们必须决定是否要自己寻求邻接和扩张。最终，这一认识是我们决定将公司出售给Chegg的原因之一，Chegg拥有更广泛的用户基础和产品协同效应，这是我们单靠自己无法实现的。任何关注切格的人都可能知道，他们非常成功地加速了edtech的数字化转型。

Darshan Somashekar co-founded  drop.io (acquired by Facebook), Imagine Easy Solutions (acquired by Chegg) and is currently co-founder of gaming platform  Solitaired and a venture partner at TMV.
  As someone who has been in edtech for nearly 20 years, this sounds like the precise moment to capitalize on all the newfound interest. Which is why what I’m about to say might be surprising: I’m leaving edtech for the world of gaming with my new company,  Solitaired.
 I first got into edtech in high school, when a friend and I founded EasyBib, a website that helped students cite sources for their papers. At the time, we were just students who felt there had to be a better way than formatting tedious citations for research papers by hand. But as we dove into the business further, we realized there was a lot to like about bibliographies and education technology in general.
 For one, the education market is large. There are more than 56 million K-16 students in the U.S., and over 1.3 billion globally. Federal, state and local governments spend an aggregate of  5% of GDP on education, and that doesn’t even include what students and parents spend on content and technology.
 Secondly, it’s structured. Students generally all go through the same curriculum together. That means most students have the same problem in the same way; if you solve a problem for one group of users, you’ve probably solved it for most users.
 The citation problem was just like that. When we sold our company to  Chegg,   we were already reaching four out of five students that needed bibliographies, or over 30 million students in the U.S. Edtech companies that help students with math, chemistry, homework help, tutoring and other curricular needs can build massive audiences quickly.
 Edtech that’s part of the curriculum also has high engagement. EasyBib users stayed on our site for nearly ten minutes per session, creating one citation after another for their bibliographies. For direct-to-consumer edtech companies that are ad and subscription driven, this behavior creates many monetization opportunities.
 While we grew fast, our endemic market opportunity was limited. Why? The strengths of edtech can also be its downsides, especially for a startup. On the user growth front, we focused on school relationships, marketing and SEO. But once we reached four out of every five students in the U.S., there wasn’t much more room to grow.
 To increase engagement even further, we tried a number of things: encouraging more citation creation, adding research and note-taking features and building a Chrome extension to be more ever-present in the user’s research journey. Those efforts fell short too. Ultimately, the school calendar dictated how often students needed to use us, and we were constrained by the number of research papers teachers assigned.
 These challenges can certainly be overcome. But as a startup, we had to decide if we wanted to pursue adjacencies and expansions ourselves. Ultimately, this realization was one of the reasons we decided to sell our company to Chegg, which had a wider user base and product synergies that we couldn’t achieve on our own. As anyone who follows Chegg might know, they’ve been very successful in accelerating the edtech digital transformation.
 When we began thinking about our second business, we had these lessons in the back of our mind. That’s when we discovered gaming.
title: 为什么我离开edtech，转而投身游戏行业？
title_en: Why I left edtech and got into gaming

伦敦(美联社)-欧盟监管机构周二对亚马逊提出反垄断指控，指控这家电商巨头利用其获取的数据获得相对于使用其平台的商家的不公平优势。
欧盟最高反垄断执法机构欧盟执行委员会(European Execution Commission)在两年前开始调查该公司后，发出了这些指控。让亚马逊更头疼的是，欧盟官员还启动了第二次调查，调查该公司是否偏袒使用自己的物流和配送系统的产品优惠和商家。
这是欧盟负责竞争事务的专员、执行副主席玛格丽特·维斯特格(Margrethe Vestager)遏制大型科技公司权力的最新努力。她已对谷歌处以总计近100亿美元的反垄断罚款，并在今年夏天对苹果展开了两项反垄断调查。美国也开始采取更强硬的立场，今年起诉谷歌滥用其在在线搜索和广告领域的主导地位。
负责竞争事务的欧盟专员、执行副主席玛格丽特·维斯特格(Margrethe Vestager)表示，亚马逊的规模和成功并不是问题。但“我们担心的是，非常具体的商业行为似乎扭曲了真正的竞争。”
欧盟官员将重点放在该公司作为市场和零售商的双重角色上。除了销售自己的产品，这家美国公司还允许第三方零售商通过其网站销售自己的商品。
欧盟委员会对亚马逊系统性地使用其独家访问的商业数据提出异议，以规避正常的竞争风险，并利用其在法国和德国这两个该公司在欧盟最大市场的电子商务服务的主导地位。
亚马逊可能面临高达其全球年度营收10%的罚款，根据其2019年的收益，这笔罚款可能高达280亿美元。该公司否认了这些指控。

调查人员分析了亚马逊网站上列出的8000万笔交易和1亿种产品的数据。维斯特格说，他们发现第三方产品清单和交易的“非常精细、实时的商业数据”被输入到亚马逊零售业务的算法中，这些算法决定要推出哪些新产品，它们的价格和供应商。
维斯塔格在新闻发布会上说：“换句话说，这是一个关于大数据的案例。”

随着许多欧洲国家暂时关闭不必要的商店，试图遏制冠状病毒大流行，推动更多的在线购物，零售商面临的风险已经上升。亚马逊是亚马逊的主要业务。

LONDON (AP) — European Union regulators filed antitrust charges Tuesday against Amazon, accusing the e-commerce giant of using its access to data to gain an unfair advantage over merchants using its platform.
 The EU’s executive Commission, the bloc’s top antitrust enforcer, issued the charges after it started looking into the company two years ago. Adding to Amazon’s regulatory headaches, EU officials also opened a second investigation into whether the company favors product offers and merchants that use its own logistics and delivery system.
 It’s the latest effort by Executive Vice President Margrethe Vestager, the EU commissioner in charge of competition issues, to curb the power of big technology companies. She has slapped Google with antitrust fines totaling nearly $10 billion and opened twin antitrust investigations this summer into Apple. The U.S. has started taking a tougher line as well,  suing Google this year for abusing its dominance in online search and advertising.
  It’s not a problem that Amazon is big and successful, said Executive Vice President Margrethe Vestager, the EU commissioner in charge of competition. But “our concern is very specific business conduct which appears to distort genuine competition.”
 EU officials focused on the company’s dual role as a marketplace and retailer. In addition to selling its own products, the U.S. company allows third-party retailers to sell their own goods through its site.
 The commission took issue with Amazon’s systematic use of business data that it has exclusive access to to avoid the normal risks of competition and leverage its dominance for e-commerce services in France and Germany, the company’s two biggest markets in the EU.
 Amazon faces a possible fine of up to 10% of its annual worldwide revenue, which could amount to as much as $28 billion based on its 2019 earnings. The company rejected the accusations.
 “We disagree with the preliminary assertions of the European Commission and will continue to make every effort to ensure it has an accurate understanding of the facts,” the company said in a statement. Under EU rules, it can reply to the charges in writing and present its case in an oral hearing.
 Investigators analyzed data covering 80 million transactions and 100 million products listed on Amazon’s site. Vestager said they found that “very granular, real time business data” on third party product listings and transactions was fed into algorithms for Amazon’s retail business that decide which new products to launch, their price and supplier.
  “In other words, this is a case about big data,” Vestager told a press briefing.
 Ordinary retailers take risks when they invest heavily to find new products, bring them to market and decide how much to sell them for, Vestager said. “Our concern is that Amazon can avoid some of those risks by using the data it has access to.”
 The stakes have risen for retailers as many European countries have shut nonessential shops temporarily to try to contain the coronavirus pandemic, pushing more shopping online, where Amazon is a major presence.
 The EU’s second investigation will look at the criteria Amazon uses to decide which seller’s product gets chosen for the “buy box” and for its Prime membership service, and whether that means they get preferential treatment by the company’s logistics and delivery services.
 The buy box, found on the right side of Amazon’s site, lets shoppers add items directly to their shopping baskets. The box features a single seller’s product even though multiple merchants might offer it.

A VPN, or a virtual private network, is an encrypted tunnel between two devices. Many companies rely on a VPN for remote employees, multi-office setups and internal services that are supposed to be visible to employees exclusively. For instance, if you’re working remotely, chances are you can connect to your company’s intranet and internal services by connecting to a VPN server from your corporate laptop.
  Over the past few years, there have been multiple trends when it comes to accessing your company’s internal network. Some companies rely on sophisticated access policies. Google has been going down this path with its  BeyondCorp zero trust system.
 Other companies still rely on corporate VPNs and firewalls as they are easy to implement. They often use the IPsec protocol with a VPN gateway that handles the connection to the internal network.
 If you’ve been working remotely lately, you may have noticed that this traditional VPN setup doesn’t scale well. The gateway is a bottleneck and you can experience long loading times when there are a lot of people connected at the same time.
 Going back to  Tailscale,   the startup is trying to modernize the corporate VPN. It starts with a different VPN protocol. Tailscale chose  WireGuard, a lightweight VPN protocol that relies on a combination of public and private keys to establish an encrypted tunnel between two clients.
 But Wireguard itself is just a protocol. It doesn’t tell you how you’re supposed to handle public keys, add new devices to your network, etc. Tailscale acts as the glue that brings all the separate pieces together.
 "Architecturally, I would describe Tailscale as the Control Plane and WireGuard is the data plane,” co-founder and CEO Avery Pennarun told me.
  Let’s take an example. Your company has an internal Git server and an internal documentation wiki. You have a corporate laptop and you want to access those two services. You can install the Tailscale client on three different machines — your laptop, the Git server and the wiki server.
 When you want to connect to the internal services, Tailscale asks you to log in using your company’s identity provider, such as G Suite, Okta, Active Directory, etc.
 All Tailscale clients check a coordination server to see if the connection is authorized. “It’s a drop box for public keys,” Pennarun said. When somebody leaves the company, the public key is removed from the coordination server and Tailscale no longer works. Keys are rotated regularly for improved security.
 A connection is then established between your laptop and the Git server or your laptop and the wiki server. There’s no bottleneck due to the VPN gateway as the Git server and the wiki server act as their own VPN gateways. There’s no need to expose your documentation wiki to the internet as employees first use Tailscale to access the server.
 You don’t have to open the SSH port on the server as Tailscale can find a way to establish  a connection through firewalls.
 The company is still quite small but pretty efficient. With around 20 employees, Tailscale is generating tens of thousands of client installs per month.
 You can get started for free with a single user and multiple devices. Some users have tried it with a Raspberry Pi at home so that they can connect to their local network when they’re on the move. They bring it to work later.
 By keeping customer acquisition costs very low, Tailscale has managed to raise $12 million.  Twingate is another company trying to solve the same issue, but it has made different technical choices — they rely on TLS tunnels and relays.

Apple’s had a packed fall, and today is the day of its third big product reveal event this season. This one is going to be squarely focused on the first  Macs   with Apple Silicon, the company’s first in-house processors designed for its macOS computers. 最新的进展是，尼日利亚初创公司Kuda宣布筹集了1000万美元，这是非洲有史以来募集到的最大一轮种子融资。Kuda运营着一家颇受欢迎的移动优先挑战者银行，面向消费者和(很快)小企业。这笔资金的背后是对其服务的强劲需求，以及其雄心勃勃-首席执行官巴布斯·奥贡德伊(Babs Ogendeyi)表示-不仅要成为生活在非洲大陆的人的首选银行，而且要成为散居海外的非洲人的首选银行。
他在一次采访中说：“我们想把地球上的每一个非洲人都存入银行，无论你在世界上的哪个地方。”它首先在国内市场起步：自2019年9月推出以来，它已经吸引了大约30万客户-最初是消费者，现在也是小企业-平均每月处理超过5亿美元的交易。
这笔1,000万美元的资金由欧洲风投巨头塔吉特全球(Target Global)牵头，Entrée Capital和印度国家银行投资公司(曾经是软银的一部分，现在不再)以及其他一些知名的金融科技创始人和天使也参与了这笔投资。
榜单上包括AuxMoney的创始人拉斐尔·约翰恩(Raffael Johnen)、Holvi的创始人约翰·洛伦森(Johan Lorenzen)、Stash的创始人布兰登·克里格/埃德·罗宾逊(Brandon Kriig/Ed Robinson)，以及Nubank、Revolut和Chime的天使投资者奥利弗·荣格(Oliver And Lish Jung)。
在此之前，由奥贡德伊和首席技术官穆斯蒂·穆斯塔法共同创立的Kuda已经在种子期前的一轮融资中筹集了160万美元，用于推出其服务的测试版，奥贡德伊表示，他已经在进行规模更大的首轮融资，目前还没有披露估值。
在这一年里，在肆虐的健康流行病席卷多个地区的背景下，许多人怀着一些不安的心情关注着世界经济，非洲的金融科技最近一直是聚光灯下的焦点。
最近，尼日利亚的一家支付初创公司PayStack以超过2亿美元的价格被斯普林德收购，这不仅是斯泰普最大的一笔收购，也是迄今为止尼日利亚初创公司中最大的一笔逐笔收购。紧随其后的是另一家支付初创公司InterSwitch，在Visa的投资下，该公司的估值达到10亿美元。
但事实上，专注于金融交易业务的初创公司，也包括邻近的电子商务行业(参见：Jumia，该地区首家上市的风险投资初创公司)一直是该地区所有科技公司中最受关注的公司之一，它们的服务也大多被广泛采用。
原因是合乎逻辑的。作为一个大陆，非洲是世界上人口最多但经济较不发达的大陆之一。在我们的现代，数字包容已经成为金融包容的代名词。因此，随着人们开始认真地采用移动技术，这些用户代表着一个巨大的机遇：存在被压抑的需求，竞争相对稀少。
这意味着要做出一系列努力，利用手机使用量的增长，为人们提供服务，让他们进行交易，而不是只使用现金进行面对面交易。其中包括Mpesa这样的创新服务，它使用个人手机(可以是基本功能手机)作为银行账户的代理，允许人们使用自己的电话号码和预付费账户进行支付。
尼日利亚-目前非洲最大的单一经济体-也一直处于金融科技许多活动的中心，库达一直在抓住这个机会。
在它的案例中，这是从从头开始建立库达的足迹开始的。
挑战者银行的崛起一直是消费者金融科技世界中比较有趣的发展之一，N26、Monzo、Starling、Chime、NuBank和Revolut等公司在年轻用户中发现了很多吸引力。
但与其中许多银行不同的是，库达没有与其他银行合作管理和支持这家挑战者银行的存款，而是反过来专注于客户服务，并围绕资金管理建立用户友好的体验和增值服务。取而代之的是，库达获得了尼日利亚央行颁发的小额信贷银行牌照。
这意味着它管理支付、转账和发行借记卡(与Visa和万事达卡合作)。他说，它还与现有银行Zenith Bank、Guaranted Trust和Access Bank建立了合作伙伴关系，让人们在需要时可以进入银行进行实物存款和取款。
他说：“我们已经在内部建立了核心银行服务，因此我们拥有全套服务。”“这意味着我们不必依赖另一家金融机构。我们可能会选择在某些产品上进行合作，但我们并不一定要这样做。“。他补充说，该计划将是在我们认为关键的地区获得完整的许可证，但也可能在现有基础设施使其更合乎逻辑的其他地区进行合作。
他补充说：“获得完整牌照的原因是为了赚钱。”“作为一家银行，你需要能够放贷，而在尼日利亚，如果你没有完整的执照，就很难放贷和赚钱。”
拥有账户是免费的，因此久田通过其他服务赚钱。其中，用户可以直接从酷达应用程序给手机充值(大多数账户都是预付费的)，所以酷达在这笔交易中充当了一种经纪人的角色，并从这笔交易中提取一定比例的费用。
用户还可以通过这款应用支付账单，Kuda也会收取一定比例的佣金。而且，与其他银行一样，库达管理其流通股，并将其投资于国库券、共同基金以及很快就会推出的其他信贷产品。他表示，也有从借记交易中收取的费用，但这些并不是真正的关注点。
库达的移动优先界面与许多围绕应用程序打造的新一波银行服务没有什么不同，包括其目标不仅仅是一个储存资金的“哑盒”。
奥贡德伊说，在库达的案例中，它使用机器学习来个性化每个客户，为其用户生成建议的预算和节省计划。他说：“我们的信贷服务的计划是，我们将根据你现有的消费习惯，以我们发行的金额和条款为基础。”
这将重点放在与库达瞄准的那种客户的消费上相吻合。奥贡德伊说，大约70%的尼日利亚人年龄在30岁以下，他们是“聪明和有创业精神”的人。
尽管Kuda的精简版可用于功能设备-首先，它缺乏基于人工智能的资金管理功能-但这家初创公司主要针对购买和使用智能手机的人群，拥有那种意味着他们积极存钱和花钱的收入和生活方式，在越来越多的情况下，还经营着自己的企业。这种重叠意味着“瞄准小企业主并不会太偏离我们最初的年轻消费者的商业模式，”他说。
他表示，虽然一些用户已经在通过Kuda运营他们的一些小企业银行业务，但到2021年第一季度，将推出一款更正式的小企业产品，具有更多为这些用户量身定做的功能。
奥贡德伊表示，尽管许多人对疫情感到不确定，但库达的相对成功以及对挑战者银行未来的乐观情绪，帮助该公司相对容易地完成了这轮种子融资(并很快筹集到其他资金)。
塔吉特全球(Target Global)合伙人里卡多·舍费尔(Ricardo Schäfer)博士在一份声明中表示：“数字挑战者银行的出现，为客户提供了免费、数字化的银行体验，而且比传统银行提供的服务要好得多，在全球范围内取得了巨大成功。”库达是非洲领先的数字挑战者银行之一，也是非洲大陆增长最快的金融技术公司之一。我们非常高兴能与巴布斯、穆斯蒂和整个库达团队合作，进一步巩固他们自成立以来的奇妙势头，并支持他们将公司提升到一个新的水平。“。他加入了库达董事会的行列，参与了这轮融资。
Entrée Capital合伙人阿维·埃亚尔(Avi EYAL)补充称：“库达坚持不懈的干劲和快速执行的能力，使其在金融和银行业开创了一种极具颠覆性的商业模式。”
任何一家来自非洲大陆的初创企业，其融资都非常罕见，因此有关非洲初创企业的报道也必须放在非洲初创企业在全球市场融资面临的更大挑战的背景下来看待，全球市场似乎普遍严重偏向发达经济体(以及硅谷等特定地区的初创企业)和更知名的创始人(这往往倾向于偏向男性)。
“归根结底，我认为双方都有工作要做，”他在谈到投资者、创始人和建设更强大的非洲生态系统的形势时说。“对投资者而言，他们中更多的人需要认识到非洲大陆的价值。而在创业方面，要理解投资者如何投资才能让他们跨过这条线，还有很多工作要做。
“不幸的是，我们没有太多非洲投资者。我相信，有钱人通常会把钱给他们了解和联系的人。如果你经历过某个机构(工作或学校)，就更容易从该机构中的某个人那里获得资金，这并不令人惊讶。“他说。“我的第一笔投资来自一位和我一起上学的朋友。”

In the latest development,  Kuda, a startup out of Nigeria that operates a popular mobile-first challenger bank for consumers and (soon) small businesses, is announcing that it has raised $10 million — the biggest seed round ever to be raised in Africa. The funding comes on the back of strong demand for its services and its ambitions — according CEO Babs Ogundeyi — to become the go-to bank not just for those living on the continent, but for the African diaspora.
 “We want to bank every African on the planet, wherever you are in the world,” he said in an interview. It’s starting first in its home market: since launching in September 2019, it has picked up around 300,000 customers — first consumers and now also small businesses — and on average processes over $500 million of transactions each month.
  The $10 million is being led by Target Global, the  giant VC out of Europe, with  Entrée Capital and SBI Investment (once part of SoftBank, now no longer) also participating, along with a number of other notable individual fintech founders and angels.
 The list includes Raffael Johnen (founder of Auxmoney), Johan Lorenzen (founder of Holvi), Brandon Krieg/Ed Robinson (founders of Stash), and Oliver and Lish Jung (angel investors in Nubank, Revolut, and Chime).
 Prior to this Kuda — which is co-founded by Ogundeyi and CTO Musty Mustapha — had raised $1.6 million in a pre-seed round to launch a beta of its service, and Ogundeyi said he’s already working on a much bigger Series A. No valuation is currently being disclosed.
 In a year where many have been watching the world economy with some trepidation on the back of a raging health pandemic hitting multiple geographies, fintech in Africa has been in the spotlight of late.
 Most recently,  Paystack  — a payments startup out of Nigeria — got  acquired by Stripe for over $200 million , making it not only Stripe’s biggest acquisition, but the largest exit-by-acquisition to-date for any Nigerian startup. That news followed closely on the heels of  Interswitch , another payments startup,  hitting a $1 billion valuation  on the back of an investment from Visa.
 But in truth, startups focused around the business of financial transactions — which also includes the adjacent industry of e-commerce (See:  Jumia, the first venture-backed startup out of the region to go public) have been some of the most eagerly-watched, and their services mostly widely-adopted, of all tech plays in the region.
 The reason is logical. As a contintent, Africa is one of the most populous, yet one of the more underdeveloped economically, continents in the world. And in our modern times, digital inclusion has become synonymous with financial inclusion. So, as the population begins to adopt mobile technology in earnest, those users represent a big opportunity: there is pent-up demand, and competition is relatively sparse.
 That has meant a number of efforts, leveraging the growth in mobile phone usage to provide services to people to make transactions beyond those that they would otherwise only do in person, using cash. These have included innovative services like Mpesa, which uses a person’s phone (which can be a basic feature phone) as a proxy for a bank account, allowing people to pay in and pay out using their phone numbers and prepay accounts.
 Nigeria — currently the biggest single economy in Africa — has also been at the center of a lot of fintech activity, and Kuda has been taking that opportunity by the horns.
 In its case, that has started with building Kuda’s footprint from the ground up.
 The rise of the challenger bank has been one of the more interesting developments in the world of consumer fintech, with companies like N26, Monzo, Starling, Chime, NuBank and Revolut finding a lot of traction with younger users.
 But unlike many of these, Kuda does not partner with other banks to manage and back deposits with the challenger bank to in turn focus on customer service, and building user-friendly experiences and value-added services around money management. Instead, Kuda has obtained a microfinance banking license from the central bank of Nigeria.
 This means that it manages payments, transfers, issues debit cards (in partnership with Visa and Mastercard). It also, he said, has partnerships with the incumbent banks Zenith Bank, Guaranteed Trust and Access Bank for people to come in for physical deposits and withdrawals when needed.
 “We have built the core banking services in-house so we own the full stack,” he said. “It means we don’t have to piggy back on another financial institution. We may choose to partner on certain products but we don’t have to.” He added that the plan will be to get full licenses “in what we consider key regions” but possibly partner in others where the existing infrastructure makes it more logical to do so.
 “The reason for the full license is because of monetization,” he added. “As a bank you need to be able to lend, and in Nigeria if you don’t have a full license it’s hard to lend and make money.”
 Having an account is free, and so Kuda makes money through other services. Among them, users can top up their phones directly from the Kuda app (most accounts are prepaid), so Kuda acts as a kind of broker in that transaction and makes a percentage from it.
  Users can also pay bill through the app, where Kuda also makes a percentage. And, like other banks, Kuda manages its float and invests it in treasury bills, mutual funds and soon other credit products. There are also fees collected from debit transactions but these are not the real focus, he said.
 Kuda’s mobile-first interface is not unlike a lot of the new wave of banking services built around apps, including an aim to be more than just a “dumb box” for storing money.
 In its case, Kuda uses machine learning to personalize every customer, Ogundeyi said, generating suggested budgets and savings plans for its users. “The plan for our credit service is that we will base how much we issue and at what terms based on your existing spending habits,” he said.
 That focus on spending dovetails with the kind of customers that Kuda is targeting. Some 70% of Nigerians are under the age of 30, and they are “smart and entrepreneurial” said Ogundeyi.
 Although a pared-down version of Kuda is available for feature devices — it lacks the AI-based money management features, for one thing — the startup is mainly targeting the segment of the population that is buying and using smartphones, have the kind of incomes and lifestyles that mean they are actively depositing and spending money, and — in an increasing number of cases — also running their own businesses. That overlap means that “targeting small business owners doesn’t deviate from our original business model of younger consumers too much,” he said.
 While some users are already running some of their small business banking through Kuda, a more formal small business product, with more features tailored for those users, will be launched by Q1 2021, he said.
  Ogundeyi said that despite the uncertainty many are feeling around the pandemic, the relative success of Kuda and the optimism around the future of challenger banks, helped the company close this seed round (and raise other money soon) relatively easily.
 “The emergence of digital challenger banks, providing customers with a free, digital and significantly better banking experience compared to services offered by traditional banks, has seen huge success across the globe,” said Dr. Ricardo Schäfer, Partner at Target Global, in a statement. “Kuda is one of Africa’s leading digital challenger banks and one of the fastest growing fintechs on the continent. We are very excited to be working with Babs, Musty and the entire Kuda team to further build on the fantastic momentum they have had since inception and support them in taking the company to the next level.” He is joining Kuda’s board with this round.
 “Kuda’s relentless drive and ability to execute quickly has allowed it to carve out a highly disruptive business model in the finance and banking industry,” added Avi Eyal, partner at Entrée Capital.
 Funding for any startup from the continent is rare enough that stories around it must also be viewed in the context of the bigger challenges in general that African startups have with raising money in a global market, which seems to generally be heavily biased towards developed economies (and startups in specific regions like Silicon Valley) and more known-quantity founders (which often tends to skew to while males).
 “Ultimately I think there is work to be done on both sides,” he said of investors, founders and the situation of building stronger African ecosystems. “On the side of investors, more of them need to appreciate the value of the continent. And from the entrepreneurial side, there is work to be done in understanding how investors invest to get them over the line.”
  “Unfortunately we don’t have many African investors. My belief is that people with money typically will give money to people they understand and connect with. It’s not a surprise that if you have gone through a certain establishment (work or school) it’s easier to get funding from someone who was in that organization,” he said. “My first investment came from a friend who was at school with me.”
 Indeed, Ogundeyi knows something about the workings of capital from his own first-hand experience. He was actually born England to Nigerian parents, who eventually moved back to Nigeria but kept him in the UK going to British boarding schools and eventually university. Ogundeyi still splits his time between Lagos and London (which is where he was when we spoke last week). He says that he considers himself Nigerian first.
 “Nigeria has the potential to be a great national economy if it’s well harnessed,” he said. “Tech is contributing significantly to that. That is why there is a lot of interest and why we are excited to be there.”

LONDON — British start-up Hopin has seen rapid growth this year amid  demand for virtual events. That's attracted significant interest from investors.
 The London-based firm's software allows conference hosts to run their gatherings online, aiming to emulate the experience of a physical event with tools for virtual talks and networking.
  On Tuesday, Hopin announced that it's raised $125 million in a round of funding that values the firm at more than $2 billion. That marks a dramatic climb from a previous valuation of $350 million and comes just under two years since the company was founded.
 Hopin saw a spike in growth this year as the coronavirus pandemic and resulting restrictions on public life forced the cancellation of several major conferences.
 It's gone from 5,000 registered users to over 2.5 million in the last eight months, while the number of organizations hosting events on its platform skyrocketed from 1,800 to 46,000. Some of its most notable clients include NATO, the UN,  Slack and  Salesforce, which is also an investor in the company.
  Hopin's wild growth hasn't gone unnoticed by investors, who have poured over $170 million into the company since February. Its latest cash injection, a Series B round, was co-led by late-stage investors IVP and Tiger Global, while Coatue and Singaporean state funds GIC and Temasek also invested.
 Northzone partner Paul Murphy, an early investor in the firm, said there was a lot of competition when it came to backing Hopin's latest round. He added: "We always expect the first round to be competitive; what I don't usually expect is for each subsequent round to also be so competitive."
  The growth of Hopin echoes several "stay-at-home" trends in technology that have been driven by the Covid-19 outbreak. Video conferencing platforms such as  Zoom and  Microsoft Teams, for instance, saw usage spike on the back of lockdown measures around the world.
 For Hopin, which launched ahead of schedule in the spring to address increased demand, that meant having to bolster its in-house infrastructure to ensure "stability," according to founder and CEO Johnny Boufarhat. And that growth is swiftly translating into revenues, with the company claiming to generate over $20 million in annual recurring revenue.
 "We're profitable and have been growing really, really fast month-on-month," Boufarhat said in an interview Tuesday. "Our goal is to create the best product for customers and, if we continue doing that, it's going to continue at this pace."
  Some investors question the extent to which such pandemic-linked trends will continue once there's a vaccine. On Monday, for instance, shares of notable "stay-at-home" stocks like Zoom and  Netflix fell sharply after drug maker  Pfizer announced its Covid-19 vaccine was more than 90% effective in preventing infection.
 But Boufarhat says the company is ready for a broader reopening of economies, claiming Hopin's first paying customer actually wanted to use it as a "hybrid" service that would run alongside physical events.
 "If we could blueprint Hopin as a public company, it would be that we're going to invest in innovation," he said, indicating the firm's interest in eventually going public. "We're investing quite heavily into hybrid events to make it a new experience for people."
 With an extra $125 million in the bank, Hopin plans to use the fresh funds to ramp up hiring and invest in new product features. The company has grown to 190 employees from just eight in March and expects to hire an additional 150 people by the end of 2020. It's also rolling out an  Eventbrite-like marketplace called "Explore" that lets users search for events.

2020年是我人生中最不寻常的一年，这既有显而易见的原因，也有我在年初绝对没有预料到的原因。经过7年的努力建设这家小公司，Baremetrics有了一个新家。
我不会在这里埋怨的。按照我们通常的透明方式，我将列出所有大家感兴趣的顶级内容，然后我将深入讨论我们是如何做到这一点的！
现在我们已经解决了这个问题，让我们跳到完整的故事中来吧！
一年半前，我开始接受工作邀请。我们有个买家，长话短说，没能成交。那是令人难以置信的精疲力竭的六个月，我已经准备好回去工作了。
我们招募了三名新的团队成员，开启了2020年的序幕，然后COVID就来了。3月份对我们来说是艰难的，但随后的几个月实际上是我们经历过的增长最好的几个月。然而，这一过山车让我想起了经营一家公司时我不太喜欢的所有事情。
我在Baremetrics工作的大部分时间都是作为一个“管理者”而不是“制造者”度过的。但在我内心深处，我是一个创造者。我在创作时最有成就感，通常对生长或缩放事物无动于衷。然而，作为首席执行官，我坚定地扮演着管理者的角色，在创造性的“制造”方面几乎没有做过任何事情。
Baremetrics一直是我的项目中最成功的项目之一(至少在财务上是这样)，所以我有理由继续担任经理一职，因为…。为什么不行？看到这样的成功是一件很有趣的事情，特别是在开发了15年以上的软件之后！
但是，再一次，COVID冷冰冰地提醒人们，经理这个角色可能会有多么大的压力，10名团队成员和1000多名客户依赖我不把事情搞得一团糟。因此，当我在4月份收到Xenon的一封电子邮件时，我开始觉得时机恰到好处。
大约15年前，我遇到了乔纳森·西格尔(Jonathan Siegel)。他正在创建各种软件公司，我为他做了一些设计工作。他后来卖掉了自己的公司，开始了Xenon，我们一直保持联系，多年来定期报到。
去年秋天，在一位买家代我们出手后，乔纳森和我开始讨论可能的收购事宜，但当时他们能提供什么的细节并不太合理。然而，这一次，细节并没有开始变得有意义。
那么，为什么这些细节开始变得有意义呢？为什么要卖呢？尤其是在我们经历了有史以来增长最好的几个月之后？
我开始掌握的东西不仅是让我成就感(做东西)的东西，也是我实际上非常擅长的东西。
十多年前，在将TheAppleBlog出售给Gigaom之后，我决定继续前进，并在公司里呆了几年，以保持它的增长。在给公司的一封关于我离职原因的电子邮件中，奥姆·马利克(Om Malik)称我是“初学者”，这个词一直让我产生共鸣。我绝对喜欢开始做事情(这份我做过的每件事的清单上都非常清楚地表明了这一点)。
任何东西的早期阶段都会产生如此多的创造力，无论是软件、实体产品、艺术还是音乐。这是“一切顺利”的创作阶段，我从中获得了如此多的能量，而且我已经有很多年没有这样的能量了。
我还意识到，擅长创办公司的人并不总是擅长发展或管理公司的人。这家公司本身的潜力比我有能力或兴趣提供的要多得多，最重要的是，我再也不享受了。
当然，我本可以深挖几年，再坚持几年，然后想出一些新的方法来发展它，或许会有更大的结果，但我真的想花10年的时间建立一家商业分析软件公司吗？不，不太喜欢。
创建一家软件公司显然没有错，但对我来说，在个人层面上，这种兴趣已经走到了尽头。我只是做好了做其他事情的准备。
回到我在开头提到的那些细节，让我们来分析一下报价本身。
400万美元现金。在出价时，它大约是2.65倍的ARR。在科技初创公司的世界里，这听起来微不足道，但现实是，绝大多数收购都围绕着这一点(或更低)。你只是不会读到关于它们的报道，因为它们不像10-100倍的收购那样华而不实。
我们也是一家多年来一直在盈亏平衡状态下有目的地运营的公司。因此，除非你是一家将收购倍数抛出窗外的“战略收购”，否则一家增长缓慢、没有大量利润和技术上相当复杂的产品的软件公司最终不会获得巨大的收购倍数。
但这里有一些更细微的地方，最终让我对这个提议非常满意。
这太关键了。大多数收购需要创始人留在董事会2-4年才能获得“盈利”，而且很多时候是与业绩目标挂钩的，而业绩目标必须达到才能获得全额回报。要坚持数年才能真正拿到赔款的前景令人心碎，我就是对此不感兴趣。
这是收购价格的最大限制因素。我完全可以从不同的买家那里谈判出更高的收购价，但对许多人来说，我离开是不可能的。
我不希望任何人因为收购而丢掉工作，但我也不希望任何人被要求留任。就像我没有被要求留在这里一样，团队也不需要留下来。不过，在这一点上，除了我之外，所有人都不会留下来(他们的薪酬也是一样的)。
每个人都有一个价格，对我来说，我真正想要的是我们家能够在经济上退休。我相信我将来会开始做一些事情，但我真正想要的是不需要花时间去做一些…。实际上，再也不需要工作了。
作为交易结构的一部分，氙气公司保证，无论尽职调查期间发生什么，我都会带回家370万美元。这一点很重要，因为经过几个月的尽职调查，很多时候总会出现一些降低收购价格的事情：营运资金要求、未支付的PTO、未确认的收入以及其他上千件事。我对处理这件事不感兴趣。
我想要稳定，我希望370万美元的结果能达到我们家族的财务目标。✅。
2014/2015年度，我们从通用催化剂公司(General Catalyst)和贝塞默公司(Bessemer)这两家投资者那里获得了80万美元的种子资金。他们一直是很棒的合作伙伴，从来没有给我带来任何压力，让我不惜一切代价实现增长(这经常是投资者的耻辱)。他们只是在需要的时候提供帮助。
我想我们都在几年前意识到，Baremetrics不会成为他们投资的10倍，特别是在我们开始关注盈利而不是增长之后。做了七年的生意，没有任何重大的增长拐点(只是缓慢而稳定)，这意味着一个相当明确的长期结果，它不需要火箭。
我希望他们至少拿回自己的钱，但最终，为了让400万美元的收购价奏效，我们需要让他们收回投资。让他们这么做并不是一种很好的感觉，如果他们只是说：“对不起，我们需要拿回我们的钱，那当然也不是没有道理的。”
但他们都非常亲切，都同意注销自己的投资。General Catalyst(80万美元的最大份额)的回应显示了他们是多么优秀：“我们认可过去7年的工作，听起来这是团队的一个很好的着陆点。”我们非常感谢有机会一路支持你们。“。
在对我们去年失败的收购进行了数月的尽职调查后，我没有兴趣再经历一次漫长的过程。我们在收到意向书六周后就关门了。
我不会在喝水的时候吐出常见的陈词滥调，然后说：“什么都没变！”一切都会一成不变！“。因为现实情况是，新的所有者会对如何经营企业和如何打造产品有不同的看法。这是一件非常好的事情。
我可以说的是，Baremetrics不会立即集成到其他产品中，也不会被关闭。他们的目标是夺取我们要去的地方，火上浇油。他们将投入更多的资源让产品变得更好，专注于Baremetrics的强项。
我不敢相信，七年前的一天晚上，我坐在家里的办公室里，对试图计算SaaS指标感到沮丧，这导致我创办了Baremetrics。七年来，我几乎每天都在思考赤裸裸的度量标准。这是2500多天的时间，我在想这件事，…。再加上许多不眠之夜。
除了暂时不做任何类型的软件外，我还没有任何具体的计划来决定下一步要做什么。我渴望创造更多有形的东西，特别是艺术和音乐，所以我可能会花很多精力去探索更多的东西。我的大脑已经有好几年不能自由探索想法了，所以在一段时间里，我只想没有义务，看看会发生什么。
这一切都是苦乐参半，就像送孩子上大学一样苦乐参半。我对结果感到高兴，并为所取得的成就感到自豪，但对我来说，这也是一个时代的终结。
我非常感谢几十名团队成员多年来一直是公司的一部分，以及数千家尝试Baremetrics的公司。
对于成千上万使用过Baremetrics的公司，感谢你们通过信息和钱包提供的所有反馈。我从来没有想过会有这么多企业从中受益！
对于几十个团队成员来说，你们选择花大量的工作时间来帮助我建立这个小点子，这是令人羞愧的。你本可以在任何地方工作，但你选择了赤裸裸的标准。作为一名创始人，这对我来说意味着整个世界。

2020 has turned in to one of the most unusual years of my life, for both the obvious reasons but also for reasons I definitely wasn’t expecting at the start of the year.  After 7 years of work building this little company, Baremetrics has a new home.
 I won’t bury the lede here. In our usual transparent fashion, I’ll lay out all the top-level bits everyone’s interested in, then I’ll dive in to how we got here!
   Now that we’ve got that out of the way, let’s jump in to full story!
  A year and a half ago, I started entertaining offers. We had a buyer who,  long story short, didn’t work out. That was an incredibly draining six months and I was ready to get back to work.
 We kicked off 2020 by hiring three new team members, and then COVID hit. March was rough for us, but then subsequent months were actually some of the best months of growth we’d ever had. However, this rollercoaster reminded me of all the things I  don’t love about running a company.
 The majority of my time working on Baremetrics has been spent as  a “manager” and not a “maker”. But at my core I’m a maker. I’m at my most fulfilled when I’m creating and am generally indifferent on growing or scaling things. Yet, as the CEO, I’m firmly in the role of a manager and do almost zero on the creative “making” side.
 Baremetrics has been the  most successful project of mine (at least financially) by a long shot, so I justified staying in the manager role because…why not? It was kind of fun seeing something succeed like this, especially after 15+ years building software!
 But, again, COVID was a cold reminder of just how stressful that manager role can be, with 10 team members and 1000+ customers depending on me to not run things in to the ground. So, when I got an email from Xenon in April, the timing started to feel right.
  Nearly 15 years ago I met Jonathan Siegel. He was building various software companies and I did some design work for him. He went on to sell his companies and started  Xenon and we stayed in touch, checking in periodically over the years.
 Last fall, after we were ghosted by a buyer, Jonathan and I started chatting about a possible acquistion, but the details of what they could offer at the time didn’t quite make sense. However, this time around, the details  did start making sense.
  So,  why did the details start making sense? Why sell at all? Especially after we’ve had some of our best months of growth  ever?
 Something I started coming to grips with was not only what fulfills me (making things), but also what I’m actually  good at.
 Over a decade ago, after  selling TheAppleBlog to Gigaom and staying on board for a couple of years to keep growing it, I decided to move on. In an email to the company about why I was leaving,  Om Malik referred to me as a “starter” and that term has always really resonated with me. I absolutely  love starting things (as is made painfully clear  in this list of everything I’ve ever started).
 There’s just so much creativity that happens in the early phases of anything, whether that’s software or physical products or art or music. It’s the “anything goes” phase of creating that I get so much energy out of and that I haven’t really had in years.
 I also realized that the same people who are good at starting companies aren’t always the same people who are good at growing or managing them. The company itself has so much more potential than I have the ability or interest in offering and on top of that, I just wasn’t enjoying myself anymore.
  Sure, I could have dug deep and stuck it out another couple of years and figured out some new ways to grow it and maybe had a larger outcome, but did I really want to have spent 10 years of my life building a business analytics software company? No, not really.
 There’s obviously nothing wrong with building a software company, but for me, on a personal level, that interest had run its course. I’m simply ready to do other things.
  Swinging back to those details I mentioned at the beginning, let’s breakdown the offer itself.
 $4,000,000 in cash. At the time of the offer, it was roughly 2.65x ARR. In the world of tech startups, that sounds tiny, but the reality is, the vast majority of acquisitions are around that point (or lower). You just don’t read about them because they aren’t as flashy as the 10-100x acquistions.
 We’re also a company that has purposefully operated right around breakeven for years. So, unless you’re a “strategic acquistion” that throws acquistion multiples out the window, a slow-growth software company without lots of profits and a product that’s technically quite complex is ultimately just not going to get a huge multiple.
 But there are some finer points here that ultimately made me perfectly content with that offer.
  This is so key. Most acquisitions require the founder to stay on board for 2-4 years for an “earnout” and many times it’s tied to performance goals that must be hit to get the full payout. The prospect of sticking around for years to actually get the payout was soul-crushing and I just wasn’t interested.
 This was the greatest limiting factor on acquistion price. I could absolutely have negotiated a higher purchase price from a different buyer, but me walking away was a non-starter for many.
  I didn’t want anyone to lose their job due to the acquistion, but I also didn’t want anyone to be  required to stay on. In the same way that I wasn’t required to stick around, the team wasn’t either. Though, at this point, everyone other than me  will be staying on (with their same compensation as well).
  Everyone’s got a price and for me, what I’ve really wanted, was to be able for our family to financialy retire. I’m sure I’ll start something in the future, but what I really wanted was to not  need to start something…to, practically speaking, never  need to work again.
 As part of the structure of the deal, Xenon  guaranteed I’d take home $3.7m, regardless of what came up during due diligence. This was important because many times, after months of due diligence, things invariably come up that reduce the purchase price: working capital requirements, unpaid PTO, unrecognized revenue, and a thousand other things. And I wasn’t interested in dealing with that.
 I wanted stability and I wanted that $3.7m outcome to hit our family’s financial goals. ✅
  In 2014/2015 we received $800,000 in seed money from two investors: General Catalyst and Bessemer. They’ve been great partners and never put any pressure on me to grow at all cost (as is frequently the stigma investors have). They’ve simply made themselves available to help when needed.
 I think we all realized a few years ago that Baremetrics wasn’t going to be a “10x our investment” company for them, especially after we started focusing on profitabiliy over growth. Seven years in business without any major inflection points of growth (just slow and steady), makes for a pretty clear longterm outcome that  doesn’t involve a rocketship.
 I wanted them to at least get their money back, but ultimately, for the $4m purchase price to work, we’d need to ask them to walk on their investment. Asking them to do that isn’t a great feeling and it certainly wouldn’t have been unreasonable for them to just say, “Sorry, we need our money back.”
 But they were incredibly gracious and both agreed to write off their investment. General Catalyst’s (who had the lion’s share of that $800k) response showed just how classy they are: “We recognize the work that’s gone into the past 7 years and it sounds like this is a great landing spot for the team. We’re grateful for the opportunity to have supported you along the way.”
  After spending months in due diligence with our failed acquisition last year, I had no interest in having another long, drawn-out process. We’re closing six weeks after receiving our LOI.
  I’m not going to spit out the usual platitudes that come with an aquistion and say, “Nothing is changing! Everything will be the same forever!” Because the reality is, the new owners will have different opinions on how to run the business and how to build the product. And that’s a  good thing.
 What I can say is Baremetrics won’t be immediately integrated in to some other product or shut down. Their goal is take where we’ve been heading and put fuel on the fire. They’ll be putting more resources behind making the product better and focusing in on what Baremetrics is so great at.
  I can’t believe it’s  been seven years since I was sitting in my home office one evening, frustrated with trying to calculate SaaS metrics, which resulted in me starting Baremetrics. I’ve thought about Baremetrics literally every single day for seven years. That’s over 2,500 days thinking about this thing…and many sleepless nights on top of it.
 I don’t have any specific plans for what I’ll be doing next, other than not doing any kind of software for a while. I’m itching to create more tangible things, especially art and music, so I’ll likely put a lot of effort in to exploring those things more. My brain hasn’t been able to freely explore ideas for quite a few years and so for a while I just want to have no obligations and see what happens.
 This is all very bittersweet, in the same way that sending a kid off to college is bittersweet. I’m happy with the outcome, and proud of what’s been accomplished, but it’s also the end of an era for me.
 I’m incredibly grateful for the dozens of team members who’ve been a part of the company over the years and the thousands of companies who’ve given Baremetrics a try.
 To the thousands of companies who’ve used Baremetrics, thank you for all the feedback you’ve given both with messages and with your wallets. I never imagined so many businesses would have benefited from this!
 To the dozens of team members, it’s humbling that you chose to spend any amount of your working hours helping me build this little idea. You could have worked anywhere and you chose Baremetrics. That means the world to me as a founder.
title: Baremetrics被一家私募股权公司收购

在很长很长一段时间里，苹果的大多数iPad看起来基本上都是一样的。它们都有一个主页按钮，都有相似的美感，都有相似的屏幕与机身比例，只是随着时间的推移略有不同。这一切在2018年随着iPad Pro的大修而改变，从iPhone 12到iPad Air，苹果最近发布的大多数移动设备都采用了这种设计。
Air采用了苹果的最新处理器(A14)，这一点也出现在iPhone 12上。它采用了iPad Pro的一般美学和语言，没有Face ID。iPad Air的底价比前一代要高，但你可以说得到了一个更现代化的设备。
基本款iPad(329美元以上)和iPad Air(599美元以上)之间的价格差距很大，以至于大多数人不太可能在两者之间做出选择-它们并不是真正为相同的用户制造的。另一方面，Air在价格和功能上都与Pro正面交锋。
除了电源按钮上的Touch ID(这是这款机型的一个全新发展)，这款iPad绝对没有什么我们在以前的机型中没有见过的，所以这将是一次快速的回顾。大多数情况下，我们会问一个问题：花更多的钱买一台iPad Pro，而不是新的、重新设计的Air，值得吗？
与许多其他平板电脑一样，屏幕当然也会侧重于规格。新的iPad Air放弃了HOME键，换成了新的几乎是边缘到边缘的LCD屏幕，分辨率为2360x1640像素，最大亮度为500nit。这是一个很棒的屏幕。不，在某些指标上，它无法击败高端电视或旗舰手机中最好的OLED面板，但它仍然相当不错。
哦，而且它的刷新率是60赫兹--这一点值得注意，因为Air的表亲--11英寸的iPad Pro--有120赫兹的显示屏，价格稍贵一些。
IPad Air包括A14片上系统，与去年iPhone的CPU相比，它的性能略有优势，但与上一代iPad Air的A12相比，有了明显的提升。
苹果公司表示，A14还将神经引擎的性能提高了70%，这意味着更快的机器学习处理，这并不是用户总是会注意到的，但它可能会为苹果和第三方应用程序开发者开发新的和改进的功能打开大门。
相比之下，基本款Non-Air iPad配备了上一代iPad Air的A12 CPU，iPad Pro配备了A12Z，A12Z是A12的变种，除其他外，A12Z的图形性能要好得多。
与Pro相比，iPad Air的主要缺点是它只提供两个存储选项：64 GB和256 GB。64 GB的内存并不能满足所有人的需求，但后者会让价格增加150美元，这使得这款平板电脑在价格上并不像乍看上去那么有吸引力。如果升级到256 GB、11英寸的iPad Pro，价格还会再增加150美元，所以价格还是有一定差别的。然而，只有iPad Pro提供更大的512 GB和1TB大小--尽管价格更高。
值得一提的是，iPad Air有4 GB内存，而iPad Pro有6 GB内存。这可能会影响一些事情，比如在不刷新的情况下一次可以打开多少个浏览器选项卡。
在摄像系统上也有不同之处。IPad Pro有一个激光雷达传感器，可以用来改善增强现实体验等。虽然iPad Air和iPad Pro都有类似的后置广角摄像头(1MP和ƒ/1.8)，但iPad Pro增加了长焦镜头。
前置摄像头非常相似。对于Zoom通话来说，这两款应用都不是理想的选择，更不用说iPadOS了，因为每当你从视频通话应用上滑动时，iPadOS都坚持要暂停你的视频，这让人沮丧。IPad Air包括TrueDepth传感器阵列，它可以启用Face ID-通过允许iPad扫描你的脸来登录的安全方法。
相比之下，iPad Air有一个Touch ID指纹识别器，尽管它内置在电源按钮中，而不是像以前的iPad那样有一个专用的Home按钮。(很快会有更多关于这一点的报道。)。
IPad Air包括两个麦克风和两个扬声器。这意味着它与iPad Pro不匹配，iPad Pro包括五个麦克风和四个扬声器，可以根据你拿着设备的方式来调整何时以何种方式使用什么。
不过幸运的是，iPad Air的两个扬声器在横向模式(通常用来看电影)而不是纵向模式(通常用来看书)下提供立体声音频。上一次情况并非如此，这是一个受欢迎的变化。
Air的其他重要规格包括Wi-Fi 6，蓝牙5.0，28.6瓦时电池，以及USB-C端口，这与之前Air的Lightning有所不同。在这一点上，USB-C是一个行业标准，因此这一举措在未来有很多好处-尽管这确实意味着你在大多数以前的iPad上使用的有线配件在这里不起作用。
我相当喜欢iPad Air的新设计。有观点认为，由于边框更大，上一款iPad的设计让握持变得更容易，我对此很敏感，但与此同时，iPad通常很擅长拒绝无意的屏幕触摸，所以我很少觉得这是个问题。
我碰巧喜欢苹果在iPad Pro和新的iPhone12产品线中强调的扁平边框的外观和感觉，这一点也在这里。有些人喜欢以前的弧形边缘，这没什么--这只是个人喜好。但如果你确实喜欢旧的弧形设计，显然你不会那么喜欢这个。
对于平板电脑来说，屏幕在某种程度上就是关键，所以它主导着用户对设备的体验也就情有可原了。这是一个非常好的屏幕。
当然，放下屏幕意味着不再有Home键。所有这些在无家iPad Pro上起作用的手势在这里都很管用，但我不太喜欢把Touch ID放在电源按钮上。
不管朝向如何，使用起来都很笨拙。我不得不多次重试记录我的指纹，因为那条细长的金属不太适合人的手指，而且在我使用Air的很多个小时里，几乎一半的时间我都会输入密码，因为我第一次尝试读取手指的时候失败了。当你把iPad放在特定的方向时，它的角度特别奇怪。
这远算不上是交易的破坏者，但它让我恼火的次数已经够多了，我甚至可以说，如果你负担得起的话，面部识别最终成为挥霍其他方面与iPad Pro大同小异的一个更好的理由。
除此之外，它的设计也没什么新意：它是一款iPad。如果你最近用过iPad Pro，你会有宾至如归的感觉。如果你还没有，那么想象一下，在更大的屏幕上使用更多屏幕手势的iPad。
IPad Air的处理器与今年的新款iPhone--iPhone 12和iPhone 12 Pro配备的处理器相同。这款代号为A14的机型在CPU和GPU能力上都比上一代机型(去年的A13机型)更胜一筹，但苹果公司表示，它的机器学习性能几乎翻了一番。
在我们的测试中，我们发现iPad Air的CPU和GPU性能与我们预期的iPhone相当，但我们看到了一些更好的图形效果--在屏幕更大、像素更高的设备上看到这一点很好。
在这里，表演并不是真正的主旋律。它比上一代iPad Air(机身是A12)要快，但还不足以让大多数用户注意到。不过，隆起对于长寿来说是件好事。
IPad Air以更低的价格提供了iPad Pro的几乎所有最好的功能，对于大多数负担得起的人来说，它是苹果产品阵容中的最佳选择。
如果你只是想买个销售点，给孩子买一台平板电脑，或者想要一款轻巧的上网设备，基本款iPad仍然是你的最佳选择。但如果你想做更多事情，推荐Air要容易得多。
事实上，我推荐在空中购买iPad Pro的情况相当少见。如果你需要512 GB或更大的存储空间，如果你需要更大的显示屏来用铅笔创作艺术作品，或者如果你使用大量要求苛刻的3D应用程序，你可以考虑使用iPad Pro。否则，Air就是一条出路。
IPad Air和iPad Pro之间的差距如此之小，事实上，这让我强烈怀疑，苹果计划在未来几个月对iPad Pro进行重大更新(而不仅仅是提高规格)--这也是反对现在购买Pro的另一个理由。苹果似乎不太可能长久地接受Air切入Pro的销量(就像这款平板电脑一样)。
我能说出的唯一主要缺点是Touch ID在这种情况下有点烦人。
IPad Air可能比之前的Air更贵，但它提供了足够多的改进，足以证明价格是合理的-尽管配件和外围设备的高昂成本仍然让这款设备变得昂贵。尽管如此，它仍是市面上最好的平板电脑之一，而且无论苹果对Pro系列有何计划，它很可能在未来几年内为用户提供良好的服务。
note_en:
For a long, long time, most of Apple's iPads looked fundamentally the same. They all had a home button, they all had a similar aesthetic, and they all had similar screen-to-body ratios, with some minor variation over time. All of that changed in 2018 with the overhauled iPad Pro, and that design has since carried over across the majority of Apple's recently released mobile devices, from the iPhone 12 to the iPad Air.
  The Air incorporates Apple's latest processor (the A14), which is also seen in the iPhone 12. And it adopts the general aesthetic and language of the iPad Pro, sans Face ID. The base price of the iPad Air is up from that of its predecessor, but you're arguably getting a much more modern device for it.
 The price gap between the base iPad ($329 and up) and the iPad Air ($599 and up) is significant—such that most people aren't likely to struggle picking between them—they're not really made for the same users. On the other hand, the Air is butting right up against the Pro, both in terms of price and features.
 Apart from Touch ID on the power button (a totally new development in this model) there's absolutely nothing in this iPad that we haven't seen in one prior model or another, so this will be a speedy review. Mostly, we're going to ask one question: is it worth spending a bit more to get an iPad Pro rather than this new, redesigned Air?
   As with many other tablets, the emphasis specs-wise is of course on the screen. The new iPad Air drops the home button for a new, almost-edge-to-edge LCD screen with a 2,360 by 1,640-pixel resolution and 500 nits of maximum brightness. It’s a great screen. No, it can’t beat the best OLED panels in high-end TVs or flagship phones by some metrics, but it’s still quite good.
 Oh, and the refresh rate is 60Hz—that’s worth noting because the Air’s slightly more expensive cousin—the 11-inch iPad Pro—has a 120Hz display.
 The iPad Air includes the A14 system-on-a-chip, which offers small performance advantages over the CPU found in last year’s iPhones but a noticeable boost over the A12 in the last iPad Air.
 Apple says the A14 also increases Neural Engine performance by up to 70 percent—that means faster machine-learning processing, which isn’t something users are always going to notice, but it potentially opens the door for Apple and third-party app developers to make new and improved features moving forward.
 For comparison: the base non-Air iPad has the A12 CPU that the last iPad Air had, and the iPad Pro has the A12Z, a variant of the A12 that, among other things, offers drastically better graphics performance.
 The key disadvantage of the iPad Air as it compares to the Pro is that it offers just two storage options: 64GB and 256GB. 64GB is not going to be enough for everybody, but the latter adds $150 to the price, making this tablet not quite as attractive price-wise as it first seems. Going up to the 256GB, 11-inch iPad Pro adds on yet another $150, so there’s still a relevant price difference. However, only the iPad Pro offers larger 512GB and 1TB sizes—albeit at even higher prices.
 There’s another under-the-hood distinction worth mentioning: the iPad Air has 4GB of RAM, while the iPad Pro has 6GB. That can affect things like how many browser tabs you can leave open at a time without refreshing.
 There are also differences in the camera systems. The iPad Pro has a lidar sensor, which can be used to improve augmented-reality experiences, among other things. And while the iPad Air and iPad Pro have similar rear-facing, wide-angle cameras (12MP and ƒ/1.8), the iPad Pro adds a telephoto lens.
 The front-facing cameras are pretty similar. Neither is ideal for Zoom calls, to say nothing of iPadOS' frustrating insistence on suspending your video whenever you swipe away from your video call app. The iPad Air includes the TrueDepth sensor array, which enables Face ID—the security method by which you log on by allowing the iPad to scan your face.
 By contrast, the iPad Air has a Touch ID fingerprint reader, albeit one built into the power button instead of a dedicated home button as in prior iPads. (More on that soon.)
 The iPad Air includes two microphones and two speakers. That means it doesn’t match the iPad Pro, which includes five mics and four speakers and adjusts what’s being used when and in what way based on how you’re holding the device.
 Fortunately, though, the iPad Air’s two speakers provide stereo audio in landscape mode (which you’d usually use to, say, watch a movie) rather than portrait mode (which you’d usually use to read a book). That wasn’t the case last time around, and it’s a welcome change.
 Other important specs for the Air include Wi-Fi 6, Bluetooth 5.0, a 28.6‐watt‐hour battery, and a USB-C port, which is a departure from Lightning in the prior Air. USB-C is an industry standard at this point, so the upsides for the move are numerous moving forward—though it does mean that wired accessories you used with most previous iPads won't work here.
  I rather like the iPad Air’s new design. I’m sensitive to the arguments that the previous model’s design made it a little easier to hold thanks to larger bezels, but at the same time, the iPad is generally quite good at rejecting unintended screen touches, so I rarely found this to be a problem.
 I happen to like the "flat edges" look and feel that Apple has emphasized in the iPad Pro and the new iPhone 12 lineup, and that’s here, too. Some people like the curved edges from before, and that’s okay—it’s just personal preference. But if you did prefer the old curved design, obviously you won’t like this quite as much.
 With a tablet, the screen is kind of the point, so it makes sense that it dominates the user’s experience with the device. And it’s a very good screen.
 Of course, dropping that screen means there’s no more home button. All the same gestures that worked on the home-less iPad Pro work great here, but I’m not a big fan of putting Touch ID on the power button.
 It’s quite awkward to use, regardless of the orientation. I had to retry recording my fingerprint many times because that thin sliver of metal doesn’t fit very naturally to a human finger, and in my many hours using the Air, I end up typing in my passcode almost half the time because my first attempt to read my finger fails. And it’s at an especially weird angle when you have the iPad in certain orientations.
 It’s far from a dealbreaker, but it annoyed me enough times that I might even say that Face ID ends up being one of the better arguments for splurging for the otherwise mostly similar iPad Pro if you can afford it.
 Besides that, there’s not a lot new to say about the design: it’s an iPad. If you’ve used a recent iPad Pro, you’ll feel right at home. If you haven’t, well, just imagine using an iPad with more on-screen gestures on a larger screen.
  The iPad Air has the same processor that was included in this year’s new iPhones, the iPhone 12 and iPhone 12 Pro. Dubbed the A14, it’s an iterative step up over its predecessor (last year’s A13) in terms of both CPU and GPU power, but Apple says it nearly doubles machine-learning performance.
 In our tests, we found that the iPad Air generally delivered CPU and GPU performance quite similar to what we saw in the iPhones as expected, though we saw some better graphics results—nice to see on a device with this larger, higher-pixel-count screen.
    Performance isn’t really the main story here. It’s faster than the last iPad Air (which sported an A12) but not enough that most users will notice. The bump is nice for longevity, though.
  The iPad Air brings  almost all the best features of the iPad Pro to a lower price point, and it's the best pick from Apple's lineup for most people who can afford it.
 If you're just doing point-of-sale, buying a tablet for a child, or want a light Web-browsing device with few frills, the base iPad is still your best bet. But if you want to do more, the Air is much easier to recommend.
 In fact, the situations where I'd recommend buying the iPad Pro over the Air are pretty slim. You might consider an iPad Pro instead if you need 512GB or more in storage, if you need a larger display for creating art with the Pencil, or if you use tons of demanding 3D applications. Otherwise, the Air is the way to go.
 The gap between the iPad Air and iPad Pro is so small, in fact, that it makes me strongly suspect that Apple plans to introduce a major update (not just a specs bump) to the iPad Pro in the next few months—another argument against buying a Pro right now. It just doesn't seem likely that Apple is going to be fine with the Air cutting into Pro sales (like this tablet surely will) for long.
 The only major downside I can name is that Touch ID is a bit of an annoyance in this case.
 The iPad Air might be more expensive than the previous Air, but it offers enough improvements to justify the price—though the high cost of the accessories and peripherals still make this an expensive device. Nonetheless, it's one of the best tablets available, and it will likely serve users well for several years to come, regardless of what Apple has planned for the Pro line.

根据Hopin首席执行官约翰尼·布法哈特(Johnny Boufarhat)的说法，新资本的估值为21.25亿美元，使Hopin成为双独角兽。之前的投资者IVP和新的投资者老虎环球(Tiger Global)牵头了这轮融资。许多其他投资者也参与了这轮融资，包括Northzone、Salesforce Ventures、SeedCamp、Accel、DFJ Growth和Coatue。
这家初创公司筹集了更多资金并不令人意外，这是霍平宣布的2020年第三轮融资。当新冠肺炎取消了在世界各地的旅行和面对面活动时，其虚拟活动技术赶上了顺风。突然之间，霍平提出的在网上举办活动的愿景成了举办座谈会的唯一途径。(TechCrunch是Hopin的客户，这对我们选择报道此次融资活动没有影响，但我觉得值得一提的是。)。
随着2020年的推进，它的增长激增，TechCrunch在Hopin提高其首轮融资时报道了这一点。
当这家创业公司宣布上一轮融资时，Hopin表示，其平台上的“每月活动参与者”数量已经从3月份的1.6万人增加到了6月份的17.5万人。据该公司称，现在它有超过350万用户，超过5万个举办活动的团体使用它的软件。
霍宾有一个宏伟的计划。在9个月内将年度经常性收入(ARR)从0美元增长到2000万美元后，这家初创公司打算继续快速招聘，加倍投资于其产品。Boufarhat告诉TechCrunch，该公司一半以上的员工将是技术人才，他的公司目前约有50%的开发人员。
Hopin的营收和估值增长使其在初创企业表现中名列前茅。这是一家值得关注的公司。霍平希望留住Scalin：在一年左右的时间里，这家初创公司从一个人发展到215人，预计到2021年，员工人数将达到800人。
布法哈特还表示，Hopin今天实现了盈利-该公司在2月份筹集了价值650万美元的融资，几乎实现了盈利-对于一家增长如此之快的初创公司来说，这是一个令人印象深刻的壮举。
但未来呢，当新冠肺炎疫苗从一个好消息变成市场现实时会发生什么？我们认为，Boufarhat告诉TechCrunch，Hopin最初的愿景是混合活动，让IRL活动与在线体验融合在一起。因此，当全世界接种疫苗时，霍平并不认为这一事件会对其平台构成生死存亡的风险。
布法哈特解释说，并不是所有的活动都能在网上很好地翻译。一场活动越私密、越个人化，或者像这位首席执行官所说的“体验性”越强，它可能就越适合当面交流。但推动Hopin增长的很可能是企业活动，这些客户可能会在2021年到来时投资于混合活动的未来。等着瞧吧。
展望未来，鲍法哈特希望Hopin成为一个其他技术可以与这家初创公司交叉的平台。他说，这可能就是Hopin与第三方VR技术合作的方式。此外，该公司还在其原有的活动平台上增加了一些功能，比如一个新的“Hopin Events”网站，让普通人可以根据演讲者、话题和其他参数对活动进行排序。或许Hopin的活动将有助于激发人们对这家初创公司举办的活动的兴趣，使其服务比竞争对手的服务更具吸引力。
就目前的ARR而言，Hopin的定价有些过高。但如果它能保持快速增长，这家初创公司可能很快就会增长到估值水平。尤其是如果它能够在规模扩大的同时保持接近盈利的水平。让我们看看Hopin在接下来的一两个季度还能走多远，以及我们是否能在2021年初从该公司获得另一个ARR数字。

According to Hopin CEO Johnny Boufarhat, the new capital was raised at a $2.125 billion valuation, making Hopin a double unicorn. IVP, a prior investor, and new investor Tiger Global led the round. A host of other investors took part in the round, including Northzone, Salesforce Ventures, Seedcamp, Accel, DFJ Growth, and Coatue.
 That the startup raised more capital is not a surprise, this being the third round in 2020 that Hopin has announced. Its virtual events technology caught a tailwind when COVID-19 cancelled travel and in-person events all around the world. Suddenly, Hopin’s vision of hosting events online was the only way to hold confabs. (TechCrunch is a Hopin customer, which had no bearing on our choosing to cover this funding event but felt worth mentioning.)
  Its growth surged as 2020 progressed, something  TechCrunch reported when Hopin raised its Series A.
 When the startup announced its preceding funding round, Hopin said that the number “monthly attendees of events” on its platform had expanded from 16,000 in March to 175,000 in June. Now, according to the company, it has more than 3.5 million users and over 50,000 groups hosting events use its software.
 Hopin has big plans. After growing its annual recurring revenue (ARR) from $0 to $20 million in nine months, the startup intends to continue hiring rapidly to double-down on investing in its product. Boufarhat told TechCrunch that more than half of its hires will be technical talent, and that his company is currently about 50% developers.
 Hopin’s revenue and valuation growth put it in the topmost tiers of startup performance. It’s a company to watch. And Hopin wants to keep scalin: After growing from a single person to 215 in a year or so, the startup expects to reach 800 staffers in 2021.
 Boufarhat also said that Hopin is profitable today — the company was nearly profitable when it raised its February round worth $6.5 million — an impressive feat for a startup growing as quickly as it is.
 But what about the future, what happens when a COVID-19 vaccine goes from being good news to being an in-market reality? Boufarhat told TechCrunch that Hopin’s original vision was  hybrid events, allowing IRL events to merge with online experiences, we reckon. So, when the world gets a vaccine, Hopin doesn’t see the event as an existential risk to its platform.
 Not every event translates online well, Boufarhat explained. The more intimate and personal an event, or “experiential” as the CEO said, the better it probably is as in-person affair. But it’s likely the world of corporate events that are driving Hopin’s growth, and those customers may invest in a hybrid events future when 2021 shakes out. We’ll see.
 Looking to the future, Boufarhat wants Hopin to become a platform where other technologies can intersect with the startup. This may be how Hopin works with third-party VR technology, he said. And, the company is adding capabilities around its original events platform like a new “ Hopin Events” website that will allow regular folks to sort events by speaker, topic, and other parameters. Perhaps Hopin Events will help drive interest into events that the startup hosts, making its service more attractive over competing companies’ own.
 Hopin is somewhat expensively priced for its current ARR. But if it can keep up its rapid growth, the startup may quickly grow into its valuation. Especially if it can keep close to profitability as it scales. Let’s see how far Hopin can get in another quarter or two, and if we can get another ARR number out of the company in early 2021.

竞争主管玛格丽特·维斯特格表示，初步结论是，这家电商巨头利用大数据非法扭曲在线零售市场的竞争，滥用了其在法国和德国这两个其在欧盟最大的市场的市场地位。
“我们对亚马逊的成功没有异议。或者它的大小。我们担心的是非常具体的商业行为，这些行为似乎扭曲了真正的竞争。“她在宣布正式指控的新闻发布会上说。
这一行动源于欧盟竞争部门在2015年开展的一项行业电子商务调查。欧盟委员会随后于去年7月宣布对亚马逊(Amazon)在其平台上使用卖家数据的行为展开正式调查，尽管它早在2018年就开始调查第三方卖家是否处于数据劣势。
作为调查的一部分，欧盟监管机构从亚马逊(Amazon)获得了一组海量数据--涵盖其欧洲市场逾8000万笔交易和逾1亿件商品清单--以分析其业务如何使用商家数据。
亚马逊是数据驱动型的。这是一家高度自动化的公司--商业决策基于算法工具，“维斯特格说。“我们的调查显示，与第三方卖家在亚马逊平台上的挂牌和交易相关的非常细粒度、实时的商业数据系统地输入到亚马逊零售业务的算法中。”亚马逊正是基于这些算法来决定推出哪些新产品、每一单报价的价格、库存管理，以及为一款产品选择最好的供应商。
这位竞争主管表示，其初步担忧是，由于亚马逊从获取第三方卖家数据中获得的大数据优势，第三方卖家无法在价值上展开竞争。
“例如，亚马逊可以获取有关卖家产品的订购和发货数量、市场收入、访问卖家优惠的次数、与发货有关的信息--包括卖家过去的表现、消费者对卖家产品的索赔(包括激活的保修)等数据。”亚马逊从其平台上的每一位卖家、每一种列出的产品、每一次购买中获取这些数据。“她说。“我们担心的不是亚马逊零售业，而是亚马逊零售业对某一特定卖家敏感商业数据的洞察力。”相反，他们关注的是亚马逊零售业对欧盟(EU)逾80万活跃卖家积累的商业数据的洞察力，这些数据涵盖了逾10亿种产品。
维斯特格说，调查表明亚马逊能够实时汇总和合并个人卖家数据，并从中得出她所说的“精确和有针对性的”结论。
争论的焦点是，与其平台上的个人卖家相比，这种能力带来了巨大的优势，这些卖家无法访问相同级别的大数据来帮助他们的商业决策。
“许多零售商将不得不投入巨资来确定感兴趣的产品，并将它们带给消费者-当他们投资新产品或选择特定的价格水平时，他们会承担风险。”我们担心的是，亚马逊可以通过使用它可以访问的数据来避免其中的一些风险。“维斯特格补充道。
我们不同意欧盟委员会的初步断言，并将继续尽一切努力确保其准确了解事实。亚马逊占全球零售市场的份额不到1%，在我们开展业务的每个国家都有规模更大的零售商。在过去的二十年里，没有一家公司比亚马逊更关心小企业，也没有一家公司在支持小企业方面做得更多。有超过15万家欧洲企业通过我们的门店销售产品，每年创造数百亿欧元的收入，并创造了数十万个就业机会。
亚马逊现在将有机会对这些指控做出回应，之后欧盟委员会将评估证据，并就其是否认为存在违反欧盟竞争法的行为做出决定。如果它认为有这样的权利，它有权下令停止侵权行为，并处以高达公司全球年营业额10%的罚款。
欧盟监管机构发现，亚马逊在这两个市场占据主导地位，在过去的12个月里，超过70%的法国和德国超过80%的在线购物消费者从亚马逊购买了商品。
维斯特格明确指出，欧盟委员会将市场定义为“提供市场服务的平台”，而不是更一般的零售。
同样在今天，这位专员宣布对亚马逊进行第二次竞争调查-这次调查的重点是Buy Box和Prime忠诚度计划。维斯特格说，监管机构决定将亚马逊的案件一分为二，这样正在进行的对Buy Box和Prime的调查不会减缓大数据调查的进展。
在详细描述围绕Buy Box和Prime的担忧时，她说：“调查亚马逊的数据使用情况发现，亚马逊可能在其平台上设定了某些规则，人为地偏袒自己的零售产品，以及使用亚马逊物流和送货服务的卖家的产品。”因此，我们决定对这些商业行为展开第二次调查。“
Buy Box出现在亚马逊产品列表页面上，让亚马逊用户点击即可将产品直接添加到他们的购物车中。这意味着包装盒中出现的产品的卖家选择是一个关键细节。
“Buy Box是必不可少的，”维斯特格说。“它会在显眼的位置显示你对所选产品的单一卖家的报价，消费者可以直接购买该产品。”因此，赢得Buy Box对市场卖家来说至关重要，因为亚马逊上80%以上的交易似乎都是通过Buy Box进行的。
她还说，对于零售商来说，能够以亚马逊的Prime标签销售他们的产品是“至关重要的”。
“亚马逊的Prime消费者对卖家来说非常重要--不仅因为他们的数量在不断增加，还因为Prime消费者在亚马逊上的花费比其他人要多得多。”
“我们担心的是，亚马逊可能会人为地推动零售商使用自己的相关服务，”她补充道。她指的是亚马逊的物流和配送部门，她表示，这“可能会将它们更深地锁定在亚马逊自己的生态系统中”。
因此，监管机构将调查亚马逊为Buy Box和Prime制定的规则的“潜在影响”。“我们希望确保不使用亚马逊物流和送货计划的卖家也有机会在亚马逊的平台上竞争优势。”我们还希望确保零售商能够在不被亚马逊生态系统束缚的情况下，转向与之竞争的市场。“。
在欧洲监管机构推进与亚马逊(Amazon)市场行为相关的反垄断行动的同时，这家电商巨头也成为美国立法者的反垄断靶子。
上个月，美国众议院司法委员会(House Judiciary Committee)在一份反垄断报告中指责了多家科技巨头，它就是其中之一。该报告辩称，亚马逊通过其在在线零售领域的主导地位，对中小企业行使垄断权--这反过来又使其能够“以破坏自由和公平竞争的方式偏袒竞争对手，使竞争对手处于劣势”。
亚马逊对美国调查委员会的回应是激烈的反驳，称其只占全球零售业的一小部分，甚至不是美国营收最高的零售商。它还声称自己的利益与其平台上的第三方卖家一致，否认存在任何利益冲突。

Competition chief  Margrethe Vestager   said its preliminary conclusion is the ecommerce giant has abused its market position in France and Germany, its biggest markets in the EU, via its use of big data to “illegally distort” competition into online retail markets.
 “We do not take issue with the success of Amazon. Or its size. Our concern is very specific business conduct which appears to distort genuine competition,” she said at a press conference announcing the formal charges.
  The action stems from a 2015 sectoral ecommerce enquiry carried out by the bloc’s competition division. The Commission subsequently announced a formal investigation of Amazon’s use of data from sellers on its platform in July  last year, though it had begun looking into concerns about whether third party sellers were being placed at a data-disadvantage by the ecommerce giant as far  back as 2018.
 As part of the investigation, EU regulators obtained a massive data set from Amazon — covering over 80M transactions and more than 100M product listings on its European marketplaces — to analyse how its business uses merchant data.
 “Amazon is data driven. It’s a highly automated company — where business decisions are based on algorithmic tools,” said Vestager. “Our investigation shows that very granular, real-time business data relating to third party sellers’ listings and transactions on the Amazon platform systematically feed into the algorithm of Amazon’s retail business. It is based on these algorithms that Amazon decides what new products to launch, the price of each individual offer, the management of inventories, and the choice of the best supplier for a product.”
 The competition chief said its preliminary concern is thus that third party sellers are unable to compete on the merits as a result of the big data advantage Amazon gleans from its access to third party sellers’ data.
 “Amazon has, for example, access to data on the number of ordered and shipped units of sellers’ products, revenues on the marketplace, the number of visits to sellers’ offers, information relating to shipping — including the past performance of the seller, the consumers’ claims on the sellers’ products including the activated guarantees. And Amazon gets this data from every seller, every listed product, every purchase on its platform,” she said. “Our concern is not about Amazon retail — about the insights that Amazon retail has into the sensitive business data of one particular seller. Rather they are about the insights that Amazon retail has about the accumulated business data of more than 800,000 active sellers in the European Union covering more than 1BN products.
  Vestager said the investigation has shown Amazon is able to aggregate and combine individual seller data in real time and to draw what she described as “precise and targeted” conclusions from it.
 That capability gives is a huge advantage over individual sellers on its platform who do not have access to the same level of big data to help their business decisions, is the contention.
 “Many retailers will have to invest heavily to identify products of interest and bring them to the consumers — taking risks when they invest in new products or when choosing a specific price level. Our concern is that Amazon can avoid some of those risks by using the data that it has access to,” added Vestager.
  We disagree with the preliminary assertions of the European Commission and will continue to make every effort to ensure it has an accurate understanding of the facts. Amazon represents less than 1% of the global retail market, and there are larger retailers in every country in which we operate. No company cares more about small businesses or has done more to support them over the past two decades than Amazon. There are more than  150,000 European businesses selling through our stores that generate tens of billions of Euros in revenues annually and have created hundreds of thousands of jobs.
 Amazon will now have a chance to respond to the charges, after which the Commission will assess the evidence and take a decision on whether it believes there has been an infringement of EU competition law. If it believes there has it has the power to order an end to infringing conduct and impose a fine of up to 10% of a company’s annual worldwide turnover.
 In the two markets EU regulators found Amazon to be dominant, with more than 70% of consumers in France and more than 80% in Germany who made online purchases bought something from Amazon in the last 12 months.
 Vestager specified the Commission is defining the market as “platforms providing marketplace services” rather than more general retail.
 Also today, the commissioner announced a second competition investigation into Amazon — this one focused on the Buy Box and Prime loyalty program.  Vestager said regulators decided to split the Amazon cases so an ongoing investigation into the Buy Box and Prime doesn’t slow down progress on the big data probe.
 Detailing the concerns around Buy Box and Prime she said: “Looking into Amazon’s data use revealed that Amazon may have set certain rules on its platform that artificially favors both its own retail offers as well as the offers of sellers that use Amazon’s logistics and delivery services. For this reason we have decided to open a second investigation into these business practices.”
 The Buy Box appears on Amazon product listing pages — letting Amazon users click to add a product directly to their shopping cart. This means the choice of seller for the product which appears in the box is a key detail.
 “The Buy Box is essential,” said Vestager. “It prominently shows you offers for one single seller of a chosen product with the possibility for the consumer to purchase it directly. So winning the Buy Box is crucial for the marketplace sellers as it seems that more than 80% of all transactions on Amazon are channelled through it.”
 She also said it’s “of the essence” for retailers to be able to sell their products under Amazon’s Prime label.
 “Amazon’s Prime consumers are very important to sellers — not only because they’re a constantly increasing number but also because Prime consumers spend significantly more on Amazon than others would do.”
 “Our concern is that Amazon may artificially push retails to use its own related services,” she added — pointing to its logistics and delivery arms — which she said “may potentially lock them deeper into Amazon’s own ecosystem”.
 Regulators will therefore be looking into “the potential effects” of the rules set by Amazon for the Buy Box and for Prime. “We want to make sure that sellers that do not use the Amazon logistic and delivery program also have a chance to compete on the merits on Amazon’s platform. We also want to make sure that retailers can shift to competing marketplaces without being locked into the Amazon ecosystem.”
 While European regulators move forward with antitrust action related to Amazon’s marketplace practices, the ecommerce giant is also in the antitrust crosshairs of US lawmakers.
 Last month it was one of a number of tech giants called out in an  antitrust report by the U.S. House Judiciary Committee. The report argues Amazon wields monopoly power over SMEs via its dominance of online retail — which in turn enables it to “self-preference and disadvantage competitors in ways that undermine free and fair competition”.
 Amazon’s  response to the US committee’s scrutiny was a fierce rebuttal — saying it accounts for only a tiny fraction of global retail and isn’t even the largest US retailer by revenues. It also claimed its interests align with the third party sellers on its platform, denying there’s any conflict of interests.
